details.title: Adjusting software failure rates that are estimated from test data
details.standardTitle: Adjusting software failure rates that are estimated from test data

p: Daniel R. Jeske has a Ph.D. in statistics from Iowa State University. He is an Associate Professor in the Department of Statistics, and is Director of the Statistical Consulting Collaboratory. Previously he was a Distinguished Member of Technical Staff and a Technical Manager in the Performance Analysis Department of Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies. He is a member of the American Statistical Association.

authors.affiliation: Univ. of California, Riverside, CA, USA
authors.name: D.R. Jeske

p: Xuemei Zhang has a Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering from Rutgers University. She is a member of technical staff in the Supply Chain Network Division of Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies. She received a M.S. in statistics from Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J.

Loan Pham has a Ph.D. in industrial engineering from Rutgers University. She is a Senior Quality and Reliability Engineer at Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation. She received an M.S. in applied statistics from Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana.

details.abstract: Software test environments are often different from field environments. Using test data exclusively to estimate a field failure rate will not usually give a very accurate estimate. In this paper, we extend an empirical calibration methodology for adjusting the failure rate estimate obtained from analysing test data. In addition to scaling the estimated failure rate of a fault, we propose scaling the estimated number of residual faults as well. We also derive likelihood ratio tests to formally determine (from previous releases of the software) if test, and field environments are significantly different. We illustrate our new results with two telecommunications case studies. The combination of the likelihood ratio test, and the calibration methodology offers a practical way to extend the application of software reliability growth models to less formal test environments.

citations.title: Adjusting software failure rates that are estimated from test data

context.text: Predicting the failure rate based on observations from a test environment that is substantially different from the user's environment can lead to very inaccurate failure rate predictions [1].
Reference [1] provides a good overview of the vast literature on methods for identifying fault-prone modules based on software metrics.
Additional references that provide good historical perspectives on the use of NHPP as SRGM are [1], [9], and [10].

references.title: Handbook of Software Reliability Engineering
references.text: M. R. Lyu, Handbook of Software Reliability Engineering, 1996, McGraw-Hill.

context.text: A theoretical framework to transform failure rate predictions from a test environment to an operational environment using test compression factors was proposed in [2].
See [2] for further discussion.
The concept was first proposed in [2], but was only justified with a plausibility argument.

references.title: Software Reliability&#821Professional Edition
references.text: J. D. Musa, A. Iannino, K. Okumoto, Software Reliability&#821Professional Edition, 1990, McGraw-Hill.

links.abstract: Software reliability is a crucial performance factor of telecommunications network elements and operational systems. This paper describes the state-of-practice software reliability engineering (SRE) methods that we selected and organized into an SRE framework for use at Bellcore. This framework comprises several SRE methods: determination of a reliability objective for a product, development and use of operational profiles, reliability modeling and estimation (prediction) to manage system testin...

context.text: Estimating the test compression factor by comparing test data with field failure data from a previous release was proposed in [3].
Our use of calibration factors is related to the work in [3], but we calibrate individual model parameters rather than the initial field failure rate.

references.title: Software reliability engineering study of a large-scale telecommunications software system
references.text: D. W. Carman, A. A. Dolinsky, M. R. Lyu, J. S. Yu, "Software reliability engineering study of a large-scale telecommunications software system", Proc. 6th Int. Symp. Software Reliability Engineering, pp. 350-359, 1995.

links.abstract: We first describe how several existing software reliability growth models based on nonhomogeneous Poisson processes (NHPPs) can be derived based on a unified theory for NHPP models. Under this general framework, we can verify existing NHPP models and derive new NHPP models. The approach covers a number of known models under different conditions. Based on these approaches, we show a method of estimating and computing software reliability growth during the operational phase. We can use this method...

context.text: Data from previous software releases were also used in [4], where transformations which map the average failure rate of a fault in the test environment to a new rate that applies in the field environment were proposed.

When applied to the average failure rate of a fault, calibration is an example of the type of transformations discussed in [4]; but the calibration concept extends to other model parameters as well, such as the number of faults.

references.title: Quantitative software reliability modeling from testing to operation
references.text: C. Huang, S. Kuo, M. R. Lyu, J. Lo, "Quantitative software reliability modeling from testing to operation", Proc. 11th Int. Symp. Software Reliability Engineering, pp. 72-82, 2000.

links.abstract: A realistic estimate of the field failure rate of software is essential in order to decide when to release the software while maintaining an appropriate balance between reliability, time-to-market and development cost. Typically, software reliability models are applied to system test data with the hope of obtaining an estimate of the software failure rate that will be observed in the field. Unfortunately, test environments are usually quite different from field environments. In this paper, we us...

context.text: For cases where the environments differ, we extend previous work [5] on the use of empirical calibration factors to more fully characterize the mismatch.

As defined in [5], \$K_{d}\$ relates the average failure rate of a fault under the test environment, \$b\$, to the average failure rate of a fault under the field environment, \$d\$, through the ratio \$d=b/K_{d}\$.

references.title: Accounting for realities when estimating the field failure rate of software
references.text: D. R. Jeske, X. Zhang, "Accounting for realities when estimating the field failure rate of software", Proc. 12th Int. Symp. Software Reliability Engineering, pp. 332-339, 2001.

context.text: See [6] for a related use of data from similar projects.

references.title: Software reliability prediction incorporating information from a similar project
references.text: M. Xie, G. Y. Hong, C. Wolin, "Software reliability prediction incorporating information from a similar project", J. Syst. Softw., vol. 49, pp. 43-48, 1999.

links.abstract: As software grows in both size and complexity, reliability becomes a critical issue, particularly in the area of telecommunications. This case study examines a tool and procedures developed at a large telecommunications company for software risk assessment. EMERALD (Enhanced Measurement for Early Risk Assessment of Latent Defects) has been applied at all stages of the software life-cycle to indicate risk of future software problems. The tool provides information used for decision support during ...

context.text: Some of the methods, such as the EMERALD (Enhanced Measurement for Early Risk Assessment of Latent Defects) [7], are applied during both the test phase, and field phase of the software.
A good general discussion of properties of NHPP can be found in [7].

references.title: Emerald: a case study in enhancing software reliability
references.text: J. Hudepohl, W. Jones, B. Lague, "Emerald: a case study in enhancing software reliability", Proc. 8th Int. Symp. Software Reliability Engineering, pp. 93-98, 1997.

references.title: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
references.text: E. Cinlar, Introduction to Stochastic Processes, 1975, Prentice-Hall.

context.text: Additional references that provide good historical perspectives on the use of NHPP as SRGM are [1], [9], and [10].

references.title: Software Reliability Modeling
references.text: M. Xie, Software Reliability Modeling, 1991, World Scientific.

context.text: Additional references that provide good historical perspectives on the use of NHPP as SRGM are [1], [9], and [10].

links.abstract: This paper presents a stochastic model for the software failure phenomenon based on a nonhomogeneous Poisson process (NHPP). The failure process is analyzed to develop a suitable meanvalue function for the NHPP; expressions are given for several performance measures. Actual software failure data are analyzed and compared with a previous analysis.

context.text: In this paper, we apply a widely used NHPP model, the G-O model [11], to analyze both test, and field software failure data.
Using subscripts to identify R1, the likelihood equation for the G-O model is \$L(a_{1},b_{1})=a_{1}^{k_{1}}b_{1}^{k_{1}}e^{-[b_{1}s_{\cdot}a_{1}(1-e^{-b_{1}S_{1}})]}\$ (see, for example [11]).

references.title: Time-dependent fault detection rate model for software and other performance measures
references.text: A. L. Goel, K. Okumoto, "Time-dependent fault detection rate model for software and other performance measures", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 28, pp. 206-211, 1979.

links.abstract: Critical business applications require reliable software, but developing reliable software is one of the most difficult problems facing the software industry. After the software is shipped, software vendors receive customer feedback about software reliability. However, by then it is too late; software vendors need to know whether their products are reliable before they are delivered to customers. Software reliability growth models help provide that information. Unfortunately, very little real da...

context.text: The G-O model has been widely used to successfully analyze software failure data [12], and it fits our application as well.

references.title: Predicting software reliability
references.text: A. Wood, "Predicting software reliability", IEEE Comput. Mag., pp. 69-77, Nov. 1996.

context.text: Indeed, the G-O model is a special case of some very general models which includes these features (see, for example, [13]).

references.title: An NHPP software reliability model and its comparison
references.text: H. Pham, X. Zhang, "An NHPP software reliability model and its comparison", Int. J. Reliab. Qual. Saf. Eng., vol. 4, no. 3, pp. 269-282, 1997.

context.text: Reference [14] derives \$K_{d}\$ in a more general context, and also presents a case study that includes a validation data set.

references.title: Calibrating software reliability models when test data does not reflect the user operational profile
references.text: X. Zhang, D. R. Jeske, H. Pham, "Calibrating software reliability models when test data does not reflect the user operational profile", J. Appl. Stochastic Models in Business and Industry, vol. 18, pp. 87-99, 2002.

context.text: If \$(\hat{a},\hat{b})\$ denotes the MLE of \$(a,b)\$, then by the invariance principle of maximum likelihood (see, for example, [15]), the MLE of \$(c,d)\$ is given by \$\hat{c}=\hat{\overline{a}}/K_{c}\$, and \$\hat{d}=\hat{b}/K_{d}\$, respectively, where \$\hat{\overline{a}}=\hat{a}e^{-\hat{b}S}\$.

references.title: Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
references.text: A. M. Mood, F. G. Graybill, D. C. Boes, Introduction to the Theory of Statistics, 1974, McGraw-Hill.

context.text: The confidence intervals for \$M(s_{i})\$ were found using the method of Clopper & Pearson [16], and only depend on the assumption that \$N(t)\$ is a Poisson process.

references.text: C. J. Clopper, E. S. Pearson, "The use of confidence or fiducial limits illustrated in the case of the binomial", Biometrika, vol. 26, pp. 404-413, 1934.

references.text: L. Kuo, T. Y. Yang, "Bayesian computation for nonhomogeneous Poisson processes in software reliability", J. Am. Statist. Assoc., vol. 91, pp. 763-773, 1996.
